tossups.question: Multiplicative effects of one process in this technique explain why vinyl pivalate exhibits a phenomenon known as leaning. Information regarding that process in this technique is commonly summarized using diagrams in which vertical lines are drawn successively lower and further apart. Relative intensities due to one process in this technique notably follow ratios corresponding to Pascal’s triangle. The (*) spacing due to that process on the output of this technique is measured in units of hertz and quantified with the J coupling constant. The n+1 rule is useful when analyzing the output of this technique, which is notably less complex for molecules with chemically equivalent hydrogens, due to the lack of doublet and triplet peaks. For 10 points, name this technique in which molecules exhibit differing chemical shifts when exposed to a magnetic field.
tossups.answer: NMR spectroscopy [accept specific types of NMR such as H-1 NMR or Carbon-13 NMR; accept spectrometry in place of spectroscopy] (The majority of clues refer to phenomena that cause peak splitting in NMR)
tossups.answer_formatted: NMR spectroscopy [accept specific types of NMR such as H-1 NMR or Carbon-13 NMR; accept spectrometry in place of spectroscopy]
acceptable: specific types of NMR such as H-1 NMR
tossups.metadata: The majority of clues refer to phenomena that cause peak splitting in NMR

tossups.question: A historian from this country declared “history can do more than study walled gardens” in the opening of a book drafted in a POW camp. A historian from this country wrote the two-volume Feudal Society and was killed by Gestapo forces in 1944. Beatrice de Planisoles is condemned in a history of a (*) village in this country. A school of history based in this country focused on the “history of mentalities,” as exemplified in a work examining the Mediterranean during the reign of Philip II. The Annales school was founded in this country by Marc Bloch and Lucien Febevre, who emphasized the importance of the longue durée. For 10 points, name this home country of Fernand Braudel and Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie.

In a book titled for this religion's "body," Kristofer Schipper argued that this religion's perfection of the body is analogous to Christianity's salvation of the soul. One text used by this religion describes a form of meditation analogized as a wheel moving along the spine. In addition to The Secret Golden Flower, another text from this religion uses the example of a cook who uses the same (*) knife for many years because he only cuts between the joints. That text from this religion also depicts its title figure drumming on a basin after his wife dies and having a dream where he cannot tell if he is a butterfly or if the butterfly is him. The Zhuangzi is a major text in, for 10 points, what traditional Chinese faith legendarily founded by Laozi.

A character within this novel writes about the benefits of cross-pollination in the book The New Flower Power. Another character in this novel fails to shoot the eugenicist Dr. Sick during World War II, and later discovers Sick is the head of the Perret Institute. In this novel, Irie does not know the father of her child since she slept with the twins (*) Magid and Millat on the same night. A review of this novel by James Wood coined the term “hysterical realism.” In this novel, the genetically-engineered FutureMouse is the subject of protests by the radical Islamic organization KEVIN. In this novel, Clara Bowden, an immigrant from Jamaica, marries Samad Iqbal’s best friend Archie Jones. For 10 points, name this debut novel of Zadie Smith.

In Twin Peaks: The Return, Agent Cooper sticks a fork in a power outlet after hearing a character in this film say “Get me Gordon Cole.” Buster Keaton has a cameo in this film as one of three bridge players. This film’s protagonist is mistaken for an undertaker who is hired to bury a chimpanzee. A character in this film responds to the claim “You used to be big” with “I (*) am big. It’s the pictures that got small.” This film is narrated by the dead protagonist, who is first seen facedown in a swimming pool. This film ends with a character played by Gloria Swanson looking at news cameras and saying “Mr. Demille, I’m ready for my closeup.” For 10 points, name this 1950 Billy Wilder film about the aging silent film star Norma Desmond, named for a Los Angeles street.

In response to this specific process,  the “Migration with Dignity” plan was developed by Anote Tong to help people learn new job skills in New Zealand or Australia. Michael Gerrard used the example of the Syrian refugee crisis as a harbinger for the results of this process. The TOPEX/Poseidon satellite project tracks and measures this specific process. The Bramble cay is the first known animal to go (*) extinct due to coastal squeeze, a result of this process. Cities such as Shanghai and New Orleans are vulnerable to the results of this process due to their location along river deltas. For 10 points, name this consequence of climate change caused by thermal expansion and melting glaciers.
tossups.answer: sea level rise [accept any answer indicating sea level getting higher; prompt on climate change or global warming before "climate change;" prompt on glacier/ice sheet melting; prompt on flooding]
tossups.answer_formatted: sea level rise [accept any answer indicating sea level getting higher; prompt on climate change or global warming before "climate change; " prompt on glacier/ice sheet melting; prompt on flooding]
acceptable: any answer indicating sea level getting higher

tossups.question: When this organ’s fundus folds back onto its body, it takes on a so-called “Phrygian cap” appearance. One disease of this organ is negatively diagnosed when it is enlarged and non-tender, according to Courvoisier’s law. Mucosal pouches in this organ’s muscle layer are called Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. Another disease of this organ is commonly diagnosed with a positive Murphy sign. A chronic, (*) calcifying condition affecting this organ may cause it to develop a “porcelain” appearance. This organ is inflamed in patients with cholecystitis, a condition that most commonly occurs when solid aggregates from this organ block the cystic duct. For 10 points, name this organ that stores bile it receives from the liver.

One poem in this language contains a thinly veiled reference to cunnilingus, which most English translations render as "Your navel is a rounded goblet that never lacks blended wine." Another poem in this language opens with the phrase "happy are those whose way is perfect," which is followed by an acrostic of this language's alphabet. Another poetic work  in this language is the origin of the phrase "a time to (*) kill, and a time to heal," which comes after that poem opens with a phrase often translated as "vanity of vanities, all is vanity." One collection in this language contains a poem that opens "the Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want." For 10 points, name this language used to write Song of Songs, Ecclesiastes, and the Psalms of David.

A terrorist group supporting these people was purged in the Burgos Trials after the murder of policeman Melitón Manzanas. The GAL paramilitary force was created to put down resistance led by these people. Dorretxeak (door-ret-SHAY-ahk) houses were burnt during a series of blood feuds among these people termed the War of the Bands. These people operated the Gipuzkoan Company and fought against the (*) Vicuñas in Potosí. Whalers of this ethnicity were killed in Iceland in 1615 after conflict over stolen fish. These people’s language is the most linguistically isolated in the world. The ETA fought for the independence of these people. For 10 points, name this ethnic group along the Bay of Biscay in France and Spain.

A 2017 MOMA exhibition displayed a series of geometric works in this medium by Brazilian artist Hercules Barsotti. This substance was used to depict a nude woman lying with a wolf in a Kiki Smith work. It’s not fabric, but recyclable metal is sewn together with copper wire in a work titled for a “splash” of this substance by the Ghanaian sculptor, El Anatsui. In 2012, this substance was used to (*) vandalize one of Mark Rothko’s nine Seagram Murals at the Tate Modern. Sumi-e “wash painting” is a technique using this substance, which Singaporean artist Chen Chong Swee is best-known for adapting to landscape painting. It's not water, but Wang Xizhi was known for his mastery of the “running” type of an art form using this substance. For 10 points, name this substance used to write calligraphy.
tossups.answer: ink [accept pen or ink on paper/parchment; prompt on “calligraphy” or “drawing/sketch” with “created using what substance?”; do not accept or prompt on pencil or graphite/lead]
tossups.answer_formatted: ink [accept pen or ink on paper/parchment; prompt on calligraphy or drawing/sketch” with “created using what substance?; do not accept or prompt on "pencil" or "graphite/lead"]

tossups.question: One character in this novel describes a visit to Hell where she saw demons playing tennis with books. A dying man whose last request is to send his heart to his beloved is envisioned by this novel’s protagonist after he enters a cave. Many bells and cats are dropped in that character’s room, and another character is appointed governor of a fictional island, in pranks in this novel pulled by the (*) Duke and Duchess. Avellanada is credited with writing an unauthorized sequel to this novel that spurred the original author to finish its second part. After losing a duel to the Knight of the White Moon, this novel’s title character dies of a fever, never having wooed Dulcinea (“dull-sin-AY-uh”). For 10 points, name this novel in two parts about a knight-errant, by Miguel de Cervantes.

An owner of one of these businesses was forced to leave St. Louis after he was accused of encouraging boatman Francis McIntosh to murder two policemen. James Forten sponsored a business of this type after its owner was dragged through the streets of Boston with a rope around his waist. Royal Weller escaped an attack on one of these businesses in (*) Alton, Illinois. Another of these businesses was founded in Rochester by a man who engaged in a fight for his life with Mr. Covey (“CUH-vee”). An owner of one of these businesses declared “I will not retreat a single inch and I will be heard!”. For 10 points, name these businesses, abolitionist examples of which were owned by Elijah Lovejoy, Frederick Douglass, and William Lloyd Garrison.
tossups.answer: newspaper(s) [accept journal, periodical, newsrag, printing presses; prompt on “the news”]
tossups.answer_formatted: newspaper [accept journal, periodical, newsrag, printing presses; prompt on the news]

tossups.question: This quantity is cubed in the denominator of the dimensionless Bejan number for fluid pressure loss. A term for this quantity appears to the two-thirds power in the Manning formula for open channel flows. The inverse fourth power of this quantity appears in the equation for Hagen-Poiseuille flow. Relative pipe roughness is divided by 3.7 times this quantity in the Colebrook-White equation for finding the (*) Darcy friction factor. The product of this quantity and mean fluid velocity is divided by kinematic viscosity to calculate the Reynolds number. Volumetric flow rate is proportional to the product of fluid velocity, pi, and the square of this quantity. For 10 points, name this one-dimensional quantity whose constriction results in increased fluid speeds, such as in a hose nozzle.
tossups.answer: pipe radius [or pipe diameter or hydraulic radius or hydraulic diameter; prompt on descriptive answers involve pipe size with “what specific quantity for the pipe?”;  do NOT accept or prompt on (cross-sectional) area]
tossups.answer_formatted: pipe radius [or pipe diameter or hydraulic radius or hydraulic diameter; prompt on descriptive answers involve pipe size with “what specific quantity for the pipe?; do NOT accept or prompt on "(cross-sectional) area"]
promptable: descriptive answers involve pipe size with “what specific quantity for the pipe?

tossups.question: A book by University of Illinois linguist Jerome Packard argues against the idea that the use of this system results in a certain language being "morphologically impoverished." Victor Mair has argued that this system has been inaccurately referred to as monosyllabic and Joel Bellassen created a color coded method for learning this system.  Otto Rosenberg's "Four Corner Method" is used to digitally (*) transcribe this system. Dictionaries for this script distinguish words by radicals and the number of strokes needed to produce words written in this script. When used to write modern Japanese, this script is known as Kanji. For 10 points, name this logographic script used to write the language of a certain highly populous East Asian country.
tossups.answer: Chinese characters [or Hanzi; or Chinese Japanese Korean Vietnamese characters; accept Kanji before read; prompt on answers about answers about Chinese writing system or written Chinese that do not mention characters by saying "what is the script?"; do NOT accept or prompt on "Pinyin" or "Wade-Giles"; do NOT accept or prompt on answers mentioning an "alphabet"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Chinese characters [or Hanzi; or Chinese Japanese Korean Vietnamese characters; accept Kanji before read; prompt on answers about answers about Chinese writing system or written Chinese that do not mention characters by saying "what is the script?; do NOT accept or prompt on "Pinyin" or "Wade-Giles"; do NOT accept or prompt on "answers mentioning an "alphabet"]
promptable: answers about answers about Chinese writing system
written Chinese that do not mention characters by saying "what is the script?

tossups.question: When Mount Ebih fails to bow to this deity, this deity destroys the mountain with battering rams and an “evil raging wind.” This deity turns the earth’s water into blood after being violated by Shukaletuda while resting under a poplar. This goddess rejects the “good milk” and “garments of new wool” another figure offers in an account in which she initially “prefers the farmer” (*) Enkimdu to her eventual husband. This goddess later allows that husband, Dumuzid, to be taken to the underworld by Galla demons instead of her. This goddess is stripped naked and afflicted with 60 diseases after descending to the underworld to see her sister Ereshkigal. For 10 points, name this Mesopotamian fertility goddess whose worship was centered in Uruk.

In a book subtitled "Universal Organization of Society," a thinker from this country defined the title concept as "the systematization of organized experience." In addition to that author of Tektology, this country is home to a thinker who argued that states in late development of capitalism are incapable of developing production that would lead to an industrial proletariat in his book The Permanent (*) Revolution. Another thinker from this country argued that capitalist expansion would cause an uprising of colonized people and wrote Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism. The author of the April Theses was from, for 10 points, what home country of Alexander Bogdanov, Leon Trotsky, and Vladimir Lenin?
tossups.answer: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; accept Russia; prompt on Ukraine or Georgia]
tossups.answer_formatted: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; accept Russia; prompt on Ukraine or Georgia]

tossups.question: In this city, Sir John Shaw was criticized for his inaction during an attack that prompted Operation Shark. The Deir Yassin Massacre was perpetrated near this city by an organization that had previously assassinated Lord Moyne in Cairo. Mickey Marcus built a “Burma Road” that ended in this city. Avraham Stern and Lehi’s actions in this city include the assassination of (*) Folke Bernadotte. This city was the site of a battle between the forces of King Abdullah I and militias including the Haganah. The King David Hotel in this city was bombed by Irgun, a paramilitary organization led by Menachem Begin. For 10 points, name this city, home to the main offices of the Mandate of Palestine.

This composer created an opera in which the “carnal and spiritual” worlds are described in a monologue by a Moorish doctor after he tells the king that his daughter can be cured. A series of trumpet blasts on D open the Polonaise from an opera by this composer, which precedes the aria “All Men Surrender to Love’s Power.” The most successful opera by this composer of Iolante sees the title character sing “You (*) wrote to me, don’t deny it,” after he was sent a love letter which precipitates a duel. That opera was conducted by Nikolai Rubinstein at its 1879 premiere, and, like this composer’s The Queen of Spades, is based on a work of Alexander Pushkin. For 10 points, name this Russian composer of the opera Eugene Onegin and the orchestral 1812 Overture.

Berie reminiscences on her childhood in a novel whose title asks “who will run” a hospital for these animals, written by Lorrie Moore. In a story with one of these animals in the title, the narrator grinds his teeth after the king throws wine in the face of Trippetta. In that story titled for one of these creatures, the king and his advisors dress as orangutans and are burned to death by a crippled (*) dwarf serving as a court jester. Simon Wheeler delivers a story about one of these animals bought after the bulldog Andrew Jackson. Quail shot is secretly fed to one of these animals named Dan’l Webster., causing Jim Smiley to lose a bet. For 10 points, Mark Twain wrote a story about a “Celebrated Jumping” kind of what animal from Calaveras County?
tossups.answer: frogs [or Who Will Run the Frog Hospital?; or “Hop-Frog”; or “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County”]
tossups.answer_formatted: frogs [or Who Will Run the Frog Hospital?; or Hop-Frog; or The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County]
acceptable: Who Will Run the Frog Hospital?
The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County

tossups.question: Stouffer’s method from meta-analysis adapts Fischer’s method to use this statistic in place of a p-value. For a normal distribution, this statistic can be transformed into a tolerance factor for a given confidence level. It’s not the mean, but the cross product of two values of this quantity is used to normalize the outputs in principle component analysis. This quantity names a (*) test analogous to Student’s t-test for populations with known parameters. This quantity is calculated for a data point by subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation, and it is then plugged into a table to find the area under the curve. For 10 points, name this dimensionless quantity equal to the fractional number of standard deviations a data point is above or below the mean.
tossups.answer: z-score [or standard score; or normal score; or z-statistic; or z-value; or standardized variable; accept z; do not accept or prompt on standard deviation or variance]
tossups.answer_formatted: z-score [or standard score; or normal score; or z-statistic; or z-value; or standardized variable; accept z; do not accept or prompt on "standard deviation" or "variance"]

bonuses.leadin: This leader tried to kill a former advisor of his known as the “white rat” in an airplane bombing that killed Kenyan minister Bruce McKenzie. For 10 points each:
answers: Palestine statehood [accept anything pro-Palestine; prompt on anything anti-Israeli]
parts: Name this African leader. He was overthrown after he tried to annex Kagera from Tanzania under Julius Nyerere.
Amin’s fantasies involved marrying this current monarch. Colonies that gained their independence under this monarch included Uganda, Kenya, and Ghana, which was formerly known as the Gold Coast.
Amin hosted terrorists supporting this cause, who were attacked during Operation Thunderbolt. Terrorists supporting this cause threw a wheelchair-ridden 81-year old off the Achille Lauro.

bonuses.leadin: These concepts' formulator described their synchronous relationship with a distinction between the “kingdom of final causes” and the “kingdom of efficient causes.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these concepts that are initially outlined within a three-tiered hierarchy ranging from spirits to souls to entelechies. In that work, these “windowless” simple substances represent the real component of matter.
Monads were central to the philosophy of this thinker who also formulated the identity of indiscernibles and is credited with co-developing calculus independent of Isaac Newton.

Despite popularizing the term, Leibniz was not the first philosopher to discuss monads. Leibniz actually borrowed the term from The Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy, the best-known book by this philosopher who was herself educated largely through letters with fellow Cambridge Platonist, Henry More.

bonuses.leadin: In their book First, Break All the Rules, Marcus Buckingham and Curt Coffman describe the ways that people in this role can sustain employee satisfaction. For 10 points each:
answers: management [accept word forms such as managers; prompt on more general answers like boss or supervisors]
parts: Name this corporate role, whose tasks are contrasted with leadership and which involves organizing employees and resources. The scientific form of this role was developed at the Bethlehem Steel Mills.

In The Principles of Scientific Management, this engineer argued against the use of "rule of thumb" principles. This leader of the Efficiency Movement is also known as the father of industrial engineering.

This management theorist and business consultant created the management by objectives model and emphasized the importance of self control in books such as The Effective Executive and Managing Oneself.
answers_formatted: management [accept word forms such as managers; prompt on more general answers like boss or supervisors]

bonuses.leadin: A man who dies if he cries and a woman who turns into water at night confess to killing police inspector Vatsome in this author’s novel Under the Frangipani. For 10 points each:
answers: Mia Couto [accept António Emílio Leite Couto]
parts: Name this author. Tuahira and Muidinga discover Kindzu’s notebooks while hiding in an abandoned bus in this author’s novel Sleepwalking Land.
Couto writes in this language, for which he won the Camões Prize in 2013. Camões wrote The Lusiads in this Iberian language.

Portuguese author António Lobo Antunes wrote of his time in Angola working in this profession. The only character who doesn’t go blind in Jose Saramago’s Blindness is the wife of a member of this profession.

bonuses.leadin: Drosophila double-mutants for the genes stardust and bazooka fail to form these cellular junctions, which disrupts basolateral polarity in their epithelia. For 10 points each:
answers: adherens junctions [accept zonula adherens or spot adherens junctions or intermediate junctions or “belt desmosome”; prompt on ZA; do not accept or prompt on “desmosome” alone]
parts: Name these cellular junctions whose function is mediated by complexes of cadherin and catenin. These junctions are characteristically enriched in phospho-tyrosine epitopes.

The adhesive properties of adherens junctions largely result from interactions between this cytoskeletal protein and the complex of bound cadherins. This protein’s beta-form is a common loading control in Western blots.

Epithelium development in Drosophila is unique for beginning at the 14th cleavage cycle, since the first 13 nuclear divisions occur without this process. Normally, this process occurs alongside telophase and divides the cytoplasm among the two daughter cells.
answers_formatted: adherens junctions [accept zonula adherens or spot adherens junctions or intermediate junctions or belt desmosome; prompt on ZA; do not accept or prompt on "desmosome”" alone]

bonuses.leadin: Jose Luis Quintana pioneered the technique of simultaneously playing this instrument with the bongos, while Manny Oquendo is a notable performer of their more traditional “typico” style. For 10 points each:
answers: timbales [accept pailas or timbales latines; prompt on drums]
parts: Name this metal-cased, single-headed drum popular in mambo music and Afro-Cuban jazz. Tito Puente is regarded as the “King of” this instrument, which can readily be heard on his song “Oye como va”.

The influences of mambo rhythms and Afro-Cuban jazz inspired this Jazz trumpeter to write the early Latin Jazz standard “Manteca”. He is known for performing with a bent trumpet and characteristically puffed out cheeks.

The later Latin jazz style of bossa nova was heavily popularized in the US by the recordings of this jazz saxophonist who recorded “The Girl from Ipanema” for an album co-named for Brazilian guitarist João Gilberto.

bonuses.leadin: Orchestral conductors do more than wave a stick around! For 10 points each:
parts: Gustavo Dudamel, the celebrated conductor of the L.A. Philharmonic, has worked globally to create musical projects based on this program created by the Venezuelan educator José Abreu. This program’s goal is to provide music education to poor and vulnerable children.

Conductor Serge Koussevitzky commissioned many new works, including concertos for this instrument by Copland and Ravel. Ravel also wrote a concerto for this instrument to be performed by Paul Wittgenstein with only the left hand.

Serge Koussevitsky was the longtime leader of this city’s Symphony Orchestra, which along with orchestras in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Cleveland, comprise the “Big Five” orchestras of the U.S. This city’s Symphony Orchestra spends its summers at the Tanglewood Music Festival.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity’s namesake problem concerns the disparity between observed values of the vacuum energy density and theoretical values of the zero-point energy put forth by QFT. For 10 points each:
answers: Kurt Gödel [accept Gödel metric or Gödel solution or Gödel universe]
parts: Name this quantity. This quantity provides the first term in a model of the Big Bang theory centering on the presence of cold dark matter.
This German physicist originally referred to the cosmological constant as his “biggest blunder” when he included that constant in his namesake field equations.

This other scientist’s namesake metric is an exact solution to the Einstein field equations for a swirling dust cloud in which the stress-energy tensor contains two terms, one for matter density and one a nonzero value of lambda.
answers_formatted: Kurt Gödel [accept Gödel metric or Gödel solution or Gödel universe]

bonuses.leadin: On the day this event happens, “a bee circles a clover” and “a fisherman mends a glimmering net.” For 10 points each:
answers: the end of the world [answer equivalents like the apocalypse]
parts: Name this event. A Czesław Miłosz (“CHESS-waff mee-WOHSH”) poem that ends with a “white-haired old man” saying “there will be no other” occurrence of this event is titled for a “song on” it.
Czesław Miłosz is an author from this country. Wisława Szymborska (“vis-WAH-vah shim-BOR-skah”) wrote poetry in its city of Kraków.
This author’s poem “Out of the World” is dedicated to the memory of Miłosz. This man wrote “By God, the old man could handle a spade” in his poem “Digging.”
answers_formatted: the end of the world [answer equivalents like the apocalypse]

bonuses.leadin: Taylor Swift fans were unhappy when this album replaced Lover on the top of the Billboard charts for the week of September 14th, 2019. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this alternative metal album that includes the songs “Invincible” and “Pneuma.” It was its band’s first album since the 2006 release of 10,000 Days.

One of the most infamous gaps between rock albums was between this band's 1993 album The Spaghetti Incident and their 2008 album Chinese Democracy. This Axl Rose-fronted band recorded the song "Welcome to the Jungle."

Fans of this band have been waiting for a new album since the 2005 release of Hypnotize and Mesmerize. Serj Tankian is the lead singer of this band whose biggest hit begins “Wake up / Grab a brush and put a little makeup.”

bonuses.leadin: This leader’s death was kept secret by Bernhard of Saxe-Weimar to keep his troops’ morale up. For 10 points each:
answers: Gustavus Adolphus [or Gustav II Adolf; or Gustavus Adolphus the Great; prompt on Gustav or Gustavus]
parts: Name this king. This king’s death came after he entered the 1632 Battle of Lutzen with no protection, claiming “the Lord God is my armor!”.
Gustavus Adolphus led this country into the Thirty Years’ War while head of its royal house of Vasa.
Engelbrekt Engelbrektsson led a group of miners of this material in rebellion against Eric of Pomerania. Sweden produced much of Europe’s supply of this material at the Falun Mine.
answers_formatted: Gustavus Adolphus [or Gustav II Adolf; or Gustavus Adolphus the Great; prompt on Gustav or Gustavus]

bonuses.leadin: In the book Quran and Woman, Amina Wadud argued the Quran's three justifications for this practice were focused on justice, and meant to ensure that women were taken care of For 10 points each:
parts: Name this practice of taking multiple wives, which is restricted to four women by the Quran.

Wadud is also known for controversially claiming that women can hold this role when serving mixed sex congregations. In Zaidi Islam, the holder of this title has historically been equivalent to the King of Yemen.

Another Muslim feminist, Asra Nomani, dedicated her "Islamic Bill of Rights for Women in the Mosque" to this figure. According to the Stories of the Prophets, this figure was the daughter of the King of Maghreb and was later made into the mistress of the Pharaoh's harem.

bonuses.leadin: Theodore Majocchi was ridiculed for dancing and saying “I do not recall” over 200 times during the trial of this royal. For 10 points each:
answers: George [accept George III or George IV]
abolition of slavery [accept anything indicating anti-slavery]
parts: Name this person, who was depicted alongside her husband in enormous green bags in a famous cartoon. This person’s relationship with Bartolomeo Pergami was the subject of a scandalous 19th century trial.
Caroline was the wife of an extremely obese king of this name. That king’s father of the same name was denounced for “repeated injuries and usurpations” in a 1776 document.
In her quarrel with George, Caroline allied with Henry Brougham, a supporter of this cause. This cause was supported by William Wilberforce and Josiah Wedgwood.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the works of chemist Walter Stockmayer. For 10 points each:
answers: liquids [accept Stockmayer liquid or Luttinger liquid]
gels [accept gelation; accept any specific type of gel, such as hydrogels, aerogels, etc.; prompt on colloid, dispersion or emulsion]
parts: Stockmayer names a theory of these substances in which they are modelled as a collection of spheres with embedded point dipoles at their centers. Electrons in a 1-dimensional conductor act as one of these substances in a separate model created by J.M. Luttinger.

Stockmayer liquids are modelled mathematically by a potential that is a specific case of this other potential from computational chemistry, which includes a 6th power attractive and 12th power repulsive term.

With Paul Flory, Stockmayer names a modification of the Carothers equation describing the formation of one of these substances from a step-growth polymer. Agarose is a commonly used example of these substances in labs.
answers_formatted: gels [accept gelation; accept any specific type of gel, such as hydrogels, aerogels, etc.; prompt on colloid, dispersion or emulsion]
acceptable: any specific type of gel, such as hydrogels, aerogels, etc.

bonuses.leadin: In this book, the white dentist Dr. Lincoln claims “I’d rather stick my hand in a dog’s mouth” than treat the narrator’s toothache. For 10 points each:
answers: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
Henderson [accept Annie Henderson, Eugene Henderson, or Henderson the Rain King]
parts: Name this book whose narrator experiences racism and a teenage pregnancy in the town of Stamps, Arkansas. It takes its title from Paul Laurence Dunbar’s poem “Sympathy.”

I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings was written after Maya Angelou accepted a bet that she couldn’t write this type of book “as literature.” Books of this type are accounts of a person’s life written by that person.

The character of “Momma,” who is actually Maya’s grandmother, has this last name. This surname belongs to a fictional millionaire who encounters the Arnewi and Wariri tribes in Africa before returning to America to become a doctor.
answers_formatted: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
Henderson [accept Annie Henderson, Eugene Henderson, or Henderson the Rain King]
acceptable: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings

bonuses.leadin: A memorial service for this politician was tarnished by Rick Kahn’s partisan eulogy, prompting Jesse Ventura to walk out. For 10 points each:
answers: Walter Mondale [or Walter Frederick Mondale; accept Fritz Mondale]
parts: Name this senator who died in a 2002 plane crash days before an election against Norm Coleman. This senator’s televised funeral also featured a giant beach ball bouncing around the Williams Arena.
Wellstone was a member of this state’s Democratic-Farmer-Labor party. Norm Coleman was later defeated in a Senate race by Al Franken in this state.

Wellstone was replaced on the Democratic-Farmer-Labor ticket by this former presidential candidate. He lost in a landslide to Reagan in 1984 after using the slogan “where’s the beef?” to win the primaries.

bonuses.leadin: [MODERATOR NOTE: review the answerline to the first part before reading this bonus]The Spectator’s contest to determine an answer to this riddle included responses like “one is good for writing books and the other is good for biting rooks.” For 10 points each:
answers: “Why is a raven like a writing desk?” [answers must contain the words raven and desk and must indicate a similarity between the two]
parts: Name this absurd riddle posed to Alice by the Mad Hatter during a tea party in Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland. The exact phrasing is not necessary.
The Exeter Book contains numerous Anglo-Saxon riddles written in this medieval language, which evolved into a modern language. It was used to write Beowulf.
A traditional English riddle begins “As I was going to [this place] / Upon the road I met seven wives” who each had seven sacks, with each sack having seven cats, and each cat having seven kits.
answers_formatted: “Why is a raven like a writing desk?” [answers must contain the words raven and desk and must indicate a similarity between the two]
acceptable: “Why is a raven like a writing desk?”
“Why is a raven like a writing desk?”

bonuses.leadin: In an unusually dark depiction of this location, two shepherds stare at a skull and a mouse, which sit atop a rectangular pedestal containing the painting’s title phrase. For 10 points each:
answers: Arcadia [accept Et in Arcadia Ego] (The second painting is Poussin’s version)
Rome [do not accept or prompt on “the Vatican” or “Vatican City”]
parts: Name this pastoral location. This location was depicted in a separate “memento mori” painting in which four idealized peasants place their hands on a tomb containing the title phrase.

The aforementioned darker depiction of Arcadia was created by this Italian Baroque artist. The two shepherds in this artist’s version of that scene are also present in that work’s companion piece, The Flaying of Marsyas.
Guercino’s copy of Et In Arcadia Ego can be found in this Italian city, where it is on display at the Palazzo Barberini. This city also houses the Borghese Gallery and the Pantheon.
answers_formatted: Rome [do not accept or prompt on the "Vatican" or "Vatican City"]
metadata: The second painting is Poussin’s version

bonuses.leadin: With respect to Jupiter, this group of objects is defined as having a Tisserand parameter less than 2. For 10 points each:
answers: resonance [or Lindblad resonance or Kozai resonance]
parts: Name this group of minor planets whose namesake member is a centaur, which like the other members of this group, possesses a long-period, eccentric orbit but lacks evidence of a comet tail.

The Damocloids are believed to be nuclei from a family of comets, which have outgassed and gone dormant. That family is named for this comet, which has a roughly 75-year orbit and is named for an English astronomer.

The Tisserand parameter can also be used to describe stellar 3-body systems in which perturbations cause a form of this phenomenon to occur between orbital inclination and eccentricity. Another form of this phenomenon can drive spiral density wave formation and was discovered by Lindblad.

bonuses.leadin: In a book titled Friendly Visits Among people in this condition, Mary Ellen Richmond described the importance of the social environment on this condition. For 10 points each:
answers: people in poverty [accept obvious equivalents such as poor people; anti-prompt on people who are homeless]
parts: Name this condition, for which Richmond developed social casework. In the book Nickel and Dimed, Barbara Erhenreich describes living conditions for people with this condition.

Much of Richmond's work espoused this perspective of social welfare, which focuses on the resources available to people in need, instead of the problems that they face. This sort of perspective is often contrasted with a deficit perspective.
Mary Ellen Richmond is sometimes contrasted with fellow early social worker Jane Addams. With Ellen Gates Starr, Addams would go on to found this settlement house in Chicago.
answers_formatted: people in poverty [accept obvious equivalents such as poor people; anti-prompt on people who are homeless]
acceptable: obvious equivalents such as poor people
